cards.title: Hacking claim has so far only increased focus on Froome
cards.rawTitle: Hacking claim has so far only increased focus on Froome

item.title: Team Sky’s hacking claim has only increased focus on Chris Froome
item.trailText: Dave Brailsford’s surprising revelations on Monday have merely added to the speculation that surrounds the Tour de France leader and 2013 champion
item.standFirst: Dave Brailsford’s surprising revelations on Monday have merely added to the speculation that surrounds the Tour de France leader and 2013 champion
item.body:
The elegant town of Pau has been the scene of more than its share of cycling mysteries, and another one was added to the list on Monday when Sir Dave Brailsford raised a minor storm by stating that Team Sky’s lawyers were on the case of people who he suspected had hacked into Chris Froome’s training files. That was accompanied by the removal from YouTube of a video marrying what purported to be Froome’s power-meter and pulse data with television footage from the 2013 Tour finish at Mont Ventoux.

The following morning Brailsford said he would prefer to focus his attention on the day’s stage from Tarbes to the hill-top finish at Pierre Saint Martin but the genie was out of the bottle. Froome, having won the 10th stage in convincing style, was emphatic the video was a “sideshow” and that any suggestion it might imply he was using performance- enhancing methods or substances was “nuts, especially as the data in question is two years old”. It was even being reported that the 2013 champion was willing to undergo independent physiological testing and release the results to prove his innocence.

“What haven’t I done? I’ve tried to be as much a spokesman as I can for clean cycling,” Froome said. “I’ve spoken to the CIRC (Cycling Independent Reform Condition), I’ve made suggestions to the governing body to implement things like night-time testing. I’ve pointed out when I’ve felt there hasn’t been enough testing, in places like Tenerife. What else is a clean rider supposed to do?”

As Pau enigmas go, Hackgate was as nothing compared with the vexed question of how a minute quantity of clenbuterol got into Alberto Contador’s urine sample in 2010 – a contaminated food supplement, concluded the court of arbitration for sport - or just where Michael Rasmussen had been training and where the Dane went after his midnight flit from the 2007 race.

Related: Tour de France 2015: Chris Froome makes huge statement with stage win

The release and removal of the video did raise a spectre from the past, however, but of a different kind to those in the Contador and Rasmussen stories and further back Lance Armstrong’s infamous drug-denying press conferences in Pau in 1999 and 2001 during the Tour. The spectre was the 2013 race when Froome spent much of the final week protesting his probity. The media and fans were split between sceptics, believers and benefit-of-the-doubters. As he pointed out after the finish here, there is little more that he can do.

The man behind the video was a blast from several cycling pasts as well, a genial Frenchman named Antoine Vayer, who tweets under the handle @festinaboy, an ironic reference to his period spent in the mid-1990s as a trainer at the notorious French squad who were thrown off the 1998 Tour amid one of the Tour’s most dramatic doping scandals.

Vayer spent his time at the team trying to shield the handful of riders who wanted to race clean and later became a fervent campaigner against doping, in which capacity he produced a column at the Le Monde newspaper discussing his estimated power-output figures for the riders in the Tour. It is impossible to assess the accuracy of Vayer’s figures but his articles were taken seriously enough by Team Sky during the 2013 Tour for Brailsford to meet him in an attempt to convince him of Froome’s probity. The video was removed from YouTube but copies remained available online and Vayer remained defiant, stating on Twitter: “Soon a new video impossible to hack even by the best hacker lawyer.”

The video did not offer any evidence of doping or superhuman performance, always assuming the figures are genuine, which is of course impossible to say. To muddy the waters further, the bulk of the footage at the key moments does not actually show Froome but other riders. The spectacular manner in which Froome turned his legs on the Ventoux in 2013 raised questions at the time but it corresponded to the way in which the team trained, the Sky trainer Tim Kerrison told the Guardian.

Whether the figures are genuine or not, what is on show does not look suspicious. The power figures constantly oscillate but that is familiar to anyone who has used a power meter. There is a visible increase in pulse rate when Froome makes the key effort to drop Alberto Contador - as would be expected - but critically, that increase comes with a distinct time lag, which is normal. The human body is not a car where the rev counter responds instantly.

The mystery is why Sky should feel it necessary to make it public that they feared Froome’s data had been hacked, and their lawyers were on the case. The answer probably lies in the memories of 2012 and 2013, when Bradley Wiggins’ and Froome’s Tours were both infected by innuendo: strike first, in the hope that the mutterings on Twitter can be nipped in the bud. It is a blunt instrument and it remains to be seen whether it works.

item.title: Astana’s Lars Boom withdraws from Tour de France with high fever
item.trailText: The Astana rider Lars Boom, who won a muddy, scrappy stage over cobblestones in last year’s Tour de France, has dropped out of this year’s race because of a high fever
item.standFirst:
• Boom has had high fever for two days, say race organisers
• Dutchman was centre of controversy over cortisol level before race
item.body:
The Astana rider Lars Boom, who won a muddy, scrappy stage over cobblestones in last year’s Tour de France, has dropped out of this year’s race because of a high fever.

Related: Astana ignore moral code by giving Lars Boom Tour de France green light

Race organisers say the 29-year-old Dutchman has had a high fever for the last two days. Boom had been at the centre of controversy before the start.

The Movement for Credible Cycling, which applies stricter anti-doping measures than cycling’s governing body or the World Anti-Doping Agency, said it had temporarily suspended Astana after pre-race tests showed Boom had an abnormally low cortisol level. Such low readings can indicate cortisone doping but is not conclusive proof of doping.

Boom won stage five in last year’s Tour, the same day that the 2013 Tour winner, Chris Froome, crashed out of the race. Astana’s Vincenzo Nibali went on to win the 2014 Tour.

cards.title: Team Sky / Brailsford claims that Froome critics have hacked training data
cards.rawTitle: Brailsford claims that Froome critics have hacked training data

item.title: Sir Dave Brailsford fears Chris Froome critics have hacked Team Sky
item.trailText: Team Sky’s principal, Sir Dave Brailsford, said Chris Froome’s performance data had been targeted by hackers looking for signs that the rider could be using drugs
item.standFirst:
• Brailsford says rider’s data is being targeted for signs he could be using drugs
• Team principal confirms Sky have called in lawyers to investigate
item.body:
Sir Dave Brailsford believes Team Sky’s computers have been hacked by critics who are sifting through Chris Froome’s performance data for signs he could be using performance-enhancing drugs.

Brailsford is so concerned that he has consulted lawyers over the breach. Froome was repeatedly questioned during the 2013 Tour, which he won, about his performances and attitude to doping.

Related: Will anyone stop Chris Froome winning the Tour de France again? | William Fotheringham

The 30-year-old Team Sky leader has always insisted he competes clean and before this year’s race described “clowns” interpreting power data as “unhelpful”. Froome led this year’s race by 12 seconds before Tuesday’s 10th stage and Brailsford, the Team Sky principal, was asked if he was ready for a repeat of the doping questions.

“It’s part of the game, isn’t it? If he does well [on Tuesday], the rest of the Tour it’s ‘How do you know he’s not doping?’

“The question of how to prove a negative is always going to be a difficult one. We think someone has hacked into our training data and got Chris’s files, so we’ve got some legal guys on the case there.

“I would never mention a name [but] ethically and morally, if you are going to accuse someone of doping, then don’t cheat.”

Brailsford said: “I used to worry about it a lot more but I don’t any more. It’s part of the game. Just try to be honest, tell the truth, be open.” Team Sky tightly controls access to riders’ data, which can be skewed and does not account for all variables.

The team was under surveillance on Sunday night by photographers hoping to catch Froome going to sleep in Brailsford’s motorhome in Pau.

The former British Cycling performance director has brought his personal motorhome to the Tour, giving him a base to work and allowing him to sleep in the same environment every night.

Brailsford had hoped Froome would benefit from using a campervan in the same way at the Tour but the UCI amended its rules after Team Sky used one for Richie Porte at the Giro d’Italia.

The regulations were subsequently amended to dictate that riders must stay in the assigned hotels, which range in standard.

Organisers ensure teams are given fair hotel allocation across the three-week race, with teams in five-star accommodation one night and budget hotels the next.

Brailsford argues a good night’s sleep is essential for any athlete and minimum standards of accommodation should be in place.

item.title: Team Sky’s Dave Brailsford earmarks Geraint Thomas as future leader
item.trailText: The Team Sky principal Sir Dave Brailsford has earmarked Geraint Thomas as a future team leader on the Grand Tours
item.standFirst:
• Welshman supporting Chris Froome in Tour de France
• ‘Next logical step is for him to lead a team at the Giro’
item.body:
The Team Sky principal Sir Dave Brailsford has earmarked Geraint Thomas as a future team leader in the Tour de France.

“Geraint has been one of the best riders in this race,” Brailsford said on the first rest day in Pau.

“He could lead the team, but the good thing about Geraint is he will say he is there for Froomey and he means it.

“The next logical step is for him to lead a team at the Giro or Vuelta. He is a brilliant rider.”

The Welshman is twice an Olympic champion in the team pursuit and has made an impression in his previous five Tours, with his versatility particularly impressive.

Related: Team Sky’s Chris Froome warns Tour de France rivals: ‘I’m getting stronger’

At present he is working in support of Chris Froome but has ambitions to challenge for the yellow jersey himself one day and could take over as leader this year if anything happens to Froome.

When Froome crashed out of the 2014 Tour, Richie Porte was “Plan B”, but the Australian struggled to sustain his challenge.

Thomas said: “As a kid you always dream of the biggest races and going to try to win the biggest races. It would be an absolute dream to do that one day. At the moment it’s all about keeping that progression going.

“Since I left the track behind it’s felt like I’ve been improving as a climber all the time and as a rider. Hopefully this Tour I can keep doing that.

“At the moment I’m just concerned about this race and just doing what I can for Froomey.”

Froome was the second British winner of the Tour after Sir Bradley Wiggins’ triumph in 2012.

Froome was second in Olympic year, but Thomas has played down his prospects of joining the Kenya-born Briton on the podium.

He added: “Podium would be out of this world, but top 10 or top 20 would be great on a personal level as well. The main thing is doing what I can for Chris.”

cards.title: News / Froome tells rivals: ‘I’m getting stronger’

item.title: Team Sky’s Chris Froome warns Tour de France rivals: ‘I’m getting stronger’
item.trailText: Chris Froome has sent an ominous message to the rivals bidding to snatch the Tour de France leader’s yellow jersey off him, saying: ‘I’m getting stronger’
item.standFirst:
• Froome holds 12-second lead after nine stages of Tour de France
• ‘Now it’s up to other teams to put the pressure on us,’ says Froome
item.body:
Chris Froome has sent an ominous message to the rivals bidding to snatch the Tour de France leader’s yellow jersey off him, saying: “I’m getting stronger”.

The Team Sky leader has a 12-second advantage over Tejay van Garderen (BMC Racing) after nine stages of the Tour, with his other major contenders trailing by at least one minute.

Alberto Contador (Tinkoff-Saxo) is 1min 3sec back, Nairo Quintana (Movistar) 1min 59sec adrift and the defending champion Vincenzo Nibali (Astana) 2min 22sec behind.

Asked about his position on Monday’s first rest day in Pau and before Tuesday’s first Pyrenees stage, the 167-km route from Tarbes to La Pierre-Saint-Martin, Froome compared himself favourably to his condition in 2013, when he won the 100th Tour.

Related: Team Sky’s Dave Brailsford earmarks Geraint Thomas as future leader

“I think I’m in quite a different position than I was two years ago,” said Froome, who crashed out of the 2014 Tour. “I came into the race extremely ready two years ago. I’d won pretty much every race building up to the Tour and I did feel as if once I got past the halfway mark in the 2013 Tour that I was almost just hanging on to the finish.

“This year I feel as if I’ve come in much fresher, a lot more mentally prepared and I feel as if I’m getting stronger in this year’s race. Now it’s up to other teams to put the pressure on us. This is the heart of the race now. This is where all the action’s going to be happening, we’re going to see who has done their homework, who has got what in the mountains. This is where the real race in yellow truly starts.”

The route from the start in Utrecht, through the Netherlands, Belgium and northern France, was expected to challenge Froome, but he has thrived and is relishing the high mountain stages where the yellow jersey is won.

Froome, the second Briton to win the Tour after Sir Bradley Wiggins in 2012, said: “Coming into this race there was a lot of last year still in the back of my mind. This first week was really one of the biggest concerns. The big thing was not to actually lose any of the time to any of the contenders.

“It is the first mountain top finish. Everyone’s going to be looking at this as a gauge as to how things are going to go the next two weeks. It’s a very important stage, but I’m very grateful that I’m in this position now, that I’m not trying to make up time on someone else.

“To actually be in this position, to have gained quite substantial amounts of time on a lot of my big rivals, this is the dream scenario at the moment. I really just have my team to thank for that.”
